channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Israeli Forces Strike in Humanitarian Zone; Scores Reported Killed
item.description: The Israeli military warned Gazans to leave part of what it had previously designated as a relatively safe area in Khan Younis, saying Hamas had launched rockets from there.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: The Decathlete Who Picked Up a Gun
item.description: About 500 top-level Ukrainian athletes and coaches have died in the war. Volodymyr Androshchuk promised his loved ones he would make it back.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman and Oleksandr Chubko

item.title: Biden Shepherded Europe on Ukraine and NATO. What Happens Now?
item.description: President Biden’s stance on Ukraine was shaped by a deep commitment to America’s trans-Atlantic alliance. Some Europeans fear he may be among the last of his kind.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: President Biden with fellow leaders at the Group of 7 summit in Italy last month.

item.title: Netanyahu, Who Clashed With Biden, Prepares for a Delicate Farewell
item.description: The Israeli prime minister could expect a freer hand if Donald J. Trump returns to the presidency. But he must rely on President Biden for another six months.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: President Biden and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in Tel Aviv in October.

item.title: Heat Waves Are Pounding Egypt, and Often There’s No A.C.
item.description: Daily power cuts have been plaguing Egypt during an extraordinarily hot summer. Now the blackouts may be temporarily suspended, but the damage to confidence in the government has already been done.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Emad Mekay
item.media:description: Shops were closed in Cairo early this month as the government imposed blackouts to save energy.

item.title: Israel Risks All-Out War With Hezbollah. A Truce in Gaza May Reduce That Threat.
item.description: After nine months of low-level conflict between Israel and Hezbollah, the risk of all-out war is higher than ever. A cease-fire in Gaza would provide an offramp for both sides, diplomats say.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A soldier with the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon inspecting a house destroyed last week by an Israeli attack in Yarine, in southern Lebanon.

item.title: Russia Sentences Alsu Kurmasheva, American Editor, to a Penal Colony
item.description: Ms. Kurmasheva, a Russian American working for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, had been charged in relation to an antiwar book she edited.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Alsu Kurmasheva at a hearing in May. She was convicted of “spreading false information about the Russian Army,” a charge that has been used to silence critics of the invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine Strikes Debt Restructuring Deal With Creditors
item.description: The deal with private bondholders will help preserve Kyiv’s limited state budget, which is crucial to fund its military. An agreement to suspend debt payments was to expire on Aug. 1.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: An artillery unit in eastern Ukraine on Friday. The debt restructuring deal will allow Ukraine to spend more money on its military.

item.title: A U.K. Deportation Plan Cost $900 Million. Only Four People Left.
item.description: Britain’s last Conservative government spent almost a billion dollars on its controversial plan to send asylum seekers to Rwanda, the newly appointed minister for immigration said Monday.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Migrants in the English Channel in May.

item.title: At Least 6 Killed at Nursing Home in Croatia
item.description: President Zoran Milanovic called for stricter gun control after an attack that shook Croatia, where mass killings are rare. A suspect was arrested nearby.
item.dc:creator: Joe Orovic and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Police officers at the scene of a shooting at a nursing home in Daruvar, Croatia, on Monday.

item.title: Couple Who Attempted to Cross Atlantic Found Dead in Lifeboat
item.description: James Brett Clibbery and his wife, Sarah Justine Packwood, had left Nova Scotia on June 11, bound for the Azores. The authorities recovered remains believed to be theirs earlier this month.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: James Brett Clibbery and his wife, Sarah Justine Packwood.

item.title: Paul Watson, Anti-Whaling Activist, Is Detained in Greenland
item.description: Mr. Watson, the founder of the conservation group Sea Shepherd, was arrested when his boat docked in Nuuk. He could face extradition to Japan.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Paul Watson in 2018. He is known for his confrontational tactics in combating whaling.

item.title: Bangladesh Protests Inequality of Opportunity
item.description: Demonstrations set off by the reinstatement of a quota system for government jobs revealed broader resentment about the uneven distribution of wealth and opportunity.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Large demonstrations in Bangladesh, like this one in Dhaka, the capital, began early this month. Protests against a quota system for public-sector jobs have erupted many times in the past two decades.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Bouncy ‘Wonders’ Leave Some Wondering, ‘Why?’
item.description: Inflatable replicas of famous monuments popped up in a park, raising questions about art and Hong Kong’s changing place in the world.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.media:description: Among the “Inflatable Wonders” exhibition, seen in Hong Kong on Tuesday, was a rendering of the enigmatic sculptures of Easter Island.

item.title: Canada Issues Evacuation Order for Jasper National Park as Wildfires Burn in Alberta
item.description: Large blazes in the province have led to the evacuation of thousands of people.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: A wildfire on Saturday in British Columbia, which borders Alberta.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Kamala Harris’s first campaign appearance.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris is closing in on the Democratic nomination. Most of the party’s delegates have now endorsed her.

item.title: Neeraj Chopra Stars in India’s Olympic Dream
item.description: Neeraj Chopra’s triumph in Tokyo inspired athletes across the world’s most populous nation. Now his country is chasing a bigger prize: a chance to host the Games for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman, Suhasini Raj and Atul Loke
item.media:description: A wall of fame at the home of Neeraj Chopra, the Olympic champion in the javelin, in Khandra, India.

item.title: When Pakistan Tightened a Border, Thousands of Lives Were Upended
item.description: Traders in Chaman have done business in Afghanistan for generations, but that stopped when officials made it much harder to cross.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathered in Chaman, Pakistan, to protest new rules that have effectively closed the border with Afghanistan.

item.title: In Georgia’s Depressed Heartland, Pining for the Soviet Past
item.description: While most Georgians support closer integration with Western Europe, many people in industrial areas that collapsed along with Communism in the 1990s express nostalgia for the old Soviet prosperity.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Natela Grigalashvili for The New York Times
item.media:description: Davit Jakeli, right, who sells scrap metal from his home, and his neighbor looking out across Kazreti, Georgia, in May.

item.title: How to Bring a Gun to the Olympics (If Your Sport Requires One, That Is)
item.description: For members of the U.S. shooting team, competitions may be the easy part. Just getting to them takes steely nerves and careful planning.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.media:credit: David Walter Banks for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sagen Maddalena, 30, an American rifle shooter, expects her luggage to draw special attention whenever she travels to competitions.

item.title: Founder of Kakao, South Korean Tech Giant, Arrested Over K-Pop Deal
item.description: Kim Beom-su, the billionaire behind Kakao, was taken into custody on allegations of stock manipulation during a bidding war over a K-pop agency.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang, Jin Yu Young and John Yoon
item.media:description: The Kakao office at Seongnam, South Korea.

item.title: After Harris Declines, Senator Will Preside at Netanyahu’s Speech to Congress
item.description: An aide to Vice President Kamala Harris said she had a scheduling conflict but would meet with the Israeli prime minister this week.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Benjamin Cardin of Maryland, who is heading into retirement, on Capitol Hill this month. He will preside over Congress on Wednesday during an address by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

item.title: Israel Orders New Evacuation in Gaza as Aid Workers Say Bombing Kills Dozens
item.description: Israeli forces said they struck dozens of sites in Khan Younis where Hamas operated and fired rockets, and they shrank the “humanitarian zone” where civilians had been told to go.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Iyad Abuheweila
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.media:description: Palestinians rushed wounded people to Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis in southern Gaza after an Israeli bombardment on Monday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Support Builds for Kamala Harris
item.description: Plus, the head of the Secret Service testified before Congress about the assassination attempt on Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Kamala Harris made her first public appearance since President Biden’s exit from the race.

item.title: Trial Set to Start Next Year in Bombing of U.S.S. Cole
item.description: The judge reserved a courtroom for fall 2025. Seventeen U.S. sailors were killed in the bombing, which was a precursor to the 9/11 terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The bombing of the U.S.S. Cole, on Oct. 12, 2000, was seen as a precursor of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

item.title: China is hosting talks between the two main Palestinian factions, but expectations are low.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Waving the Fatah emblem during a demonstration in the occupied West Bank city of Hebron in October.

item.title: A New Candidate Must Now Defend Biden’s Legacy Abroad
item.description: More than any election in decades, this one will be marked by starkly different approaches to an era of simultaneous confrontations, from China to Russia to the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: If Vice President Kamala Harris runs against Donald J. Trump, she will be defending President Biden’s record against Mr. Trump’s radically different interpretation of recent years.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Serving in the White House “has been the greatest honor of my life,” President Biden said. He said he would complete his term in office.

item.title: World Leaders React to Biden Campaign Decision
item.description: Foreign leaders did not wade into the turmoil of U.S. politics. Many opted instead for statements of empathy that lauded the president’s record.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:description: President Biden at the NATO summit in Washington this month. He announced on Sunday that he would not seek re-election.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Biden Ends His Re-Election Bid
item.description: The president endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris to continue the race against Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: President Biden said he would address the nation about his decision later this week.

item.title: Soho Waiters Race Keeps London Servers on Their Toes
item.description: Waiters in London competed in an annual footrace designed to test their mettle, their coordination and their skill as servers.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Competing in the Soho Waiters’ Race in London on Sunday. “It’s the Olympics for us waiters,” one participant said.

item.title: Israeli Strike on Yemeni Port Will Harm Civilians, Not Houthis, Experts Say
item.description: Israel’s counterattack on the Houthis, which set a vital Yemeni port ablaze, will do little to deter the militia, Yemeni and international experts said.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Shuaib Almosawa
item.media:description: A fire at an oil-storage building on Saturday after Israel struck Hudaydah, a port city in Yemen that the Houthis hold.

item.title: You Ask, We Answer
item.description: We’re answering reader questions about this newsletter, and the news in general.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Haruka Sakaguchi for The New York Times

item.title: Bangladesh Sharply Cuts Quota System That Sparked Protest
item.description: A court ruling has sharply reduced a quota system for filling government jobs, after protests over the issue turned violent and were brutally suppressed.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Large demonstrations in Bangladesh, like this one in Dhaka, the capital, began early this month. Protests against a quota system for public-sector jobs have erupted many times in the past two decades.

item.title: Israel Intercepts Missile Fired From Yemen as Conflict With Houthis Continues
item.description: The missile launch suggested that the Yemen-based Houthi militia, which is backed by Iran, would keep up its attacks despite Israeli airstrikes on a port it controls.
item.dc:creator: Gabby Sobelman and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A fire at an oil storage facility on Saturday after Israeli strikes in the Houthi-held port city of Hudaydah in Yemen.

item.title: 7 Takeaways From Our Investigation Into a Secret Investor in Jack Ma’s Companies
item.description: Behind the scenes, China’s most celebrated and its most notorious billionaires were linked through investments worth at least $1 billion.
item.dc:creator: Michael Forsythe, Katrina Northrop and Eliot Chen

item.title: Canadian Politicians Are in No Hurry to Fight Foreign Interference in Elections
item.description: China and India have been accused of exploiting the opaque nomination contests of Canadian political parties to meddle in elections.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Cole Burston for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Sikh temple in Brampton, a suburb of Toronto. Brampton is home to the largest Sikh community in Canada.

item.title: The Billionaire Criminal Who Secretly Profited Off Jack Ma’s Deals
item.description: Confidential documents show that Xiao Jianhua, a corrupt investor tied to China’s political elite, backed the country’s most successful and revered entrepreneur.
item.dc:creator: Michael Forsythe, Katrina Northrop and Eliot Chen
item.media:credit: Mark Harris for The New York Times

item.title: The World’s Most Fashionable Judoka Is Looking for Clothes in His Size
item.description: Teddy Riner has long had trouble finding stylish apparel for his 6-foot-8 frame. Could it be time to create his own line?
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Teddy Riner, with his wife, Luthna Plocus, at the Balenciaga show at Paris Fashion Week in March 2024. He’s wearing Balenciaga.

item.title: Thomas Neff, Who Turned Soviet Warheads Into Electricity, Dies at 80
item.description: An M.I.T. physicist, he engineered an East-West deal that reduced nuclear threats and produced one of the greatest peace dividends of all time.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad

item.title: Israeli Jets Bomb Sites in Yemen Linked to Iran-Backed Houthis
item.description: The strike was retaliation for a drone attack launched from Yemen a day earlier, which evaded Israel’s defenses and hit a building in Tel Aviv, killing one person.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman, Shuaib Almosawa and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Houthi Media Center, via Agence-France Presse - Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by a Houthi media source shows a large fire in the Yemeni port city of Hodeidah after Israeli airstrikes on Saturday.

item.title: ‘There’s No Way to Turn Yourself In’: Migrants Rethink Routes to U.S.
item.description: In Tapachula, Mexico, migrants en route to the United States are being forced to reroute their journeys after President Biden’s executive order suspending and limiting asylum requests, and human smugglers are profiting.
item.dc:creator: Alex Pena, Benjamin Alfaro and Amy Marino

item.title: Houthi Drone Strike Highlights Dilemmas for Israel
item.description: Israel has few options to retaliate for the attack in Tel Aviv, which made clear the weakness of its air defense system against unmanned aircraft and heightened concerns about the threat of Iranian-backed militias.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A building in Tel Aviv that was struck on Friday.

item.title: Divisive Far-Right Politician in Ukraine Is Fatally Shot
item.description: Iryna Farion, a former lawmaker, was known for controversial campaigns to discredit Russian-speaking Ukrainians.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Iryna Farion, a linguistics professor and former lawmaker, in Lviv, Ukraine, in 2022.

item.title: Dozens Dead or Missing After China Highway Collapse
item.description: It was the second such rain-related disaster in less than three months, as extreme weather challenges the country’s extensive network of newly built expressways.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: A photograph released by China’s Xinhua news agency showing the broken bridge on Saturday.

item.title: ‘Twisters’ and the Appeal of the Sequel
item.description: When a sequel comes out, it can be an occasion to reaffirm why you love the original.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Much Is Still Unknown as Listeria Again Takes Canadian Lives
item.description: While a listeria contamination of 18 nondairy milk alternatives has killed two people and sickened 10 more, Danone seems to be concealing a key fact.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Neither Danone nor the Canadian government will say what company made the nondairy milk linked to two deaths.

item.title: How the U.S. Played a Role in Venezuela’s Election
item.description: The Biden administration helped prod the Venezuelan government to hold elections on July 28. Now, it is watching to see if the vote will be free and fair.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of the opposition candidate Edmundo González going house to house this month showing the presidential ballot to neighbors in El Junco, Venezuela.

item.title: Did Police in Kenya Catch a Serial Killer or Coerce a Confession?
item.description: After at least 10 sacks with body parts were found in a dump, a suspect was said to admit to 42 murders. But some doubt the case, and people with missing loved ones say the police were slow to help.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Brian Otieno
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times

item.title: The Olympics Is Transforming Their Neighborhood. And Kicking Them Out.
item.description: The Games brought billions to redevelop this Paris suburb. What will the thousands of homeless people who live there do?
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Immigrants sitting together inside the so-called Squat Gambetta in Seine-Saint-Denis, a suburban area east of Paris.

item.title: The Buried Book That Helped Ukraine’s Literary Revival
item.description: To keep it from Russian forces, a writer hid his last manuscript under a cherry tree. Its rediscovery became part of a flowering of interest in Ukrainian literature.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Burned books inside the printing plant that was struck by Russian missiles last month.

item.title: To Deter Day-Trippers, Venice Tested a €5 Entrance Fee. Did Visitors Stay Away?
item.description: The mayor said preliminary data suggested that the experiment was a success. But the program brought in far more money than predicted, which critics called proof of failure.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Matteo de Mayda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Inspectors checking tourists in Venice last month to verify that they had paid an entrance fee.

item.title: Bangladesh Orders Curfew to Quell Deadly Protests
item.description: For weeks, university students have been protesting a quota system for government jobs. Suppression led to a cycle of violence and now a paralyzing curfew.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Anupreeta Das
item.media:description: Police facing off with protesters in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Friday.

item.title: Death of Vietnam’s Top Leader Raises Questions of Succession
item.description: The country’s political workings are notably opaque, but for now the president, who was until recently minister of public security, is carrying out the duties of general secretary.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:description: President To Lam of Vietnam in Hanoi last month.

item.title: Blinken Says Gaza Cease-Fire Deal Is ‘Inside the 10-Yard Line’
item.description: The national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, was more cautious as both spoke ahead of next week’s visit to Washington by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, and Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said nothing about how the president would juggle the crisis engulfing his re-election bid with managing the tense relationship with the Israeli prime minister.

item.title: Houthis Launch Deadly Drone Strike on Tel Aviv, Evading Israel’s Defenses
item.description: At least one person was killed and eight others injured in a predawn attack on Friday. The Israeli military said it was investigating why it “did not identify it, attack it and intercept it.”
item.dc:creator: Gabby Sobelman, Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman, Lara Jakes and Erin Mendell
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: What Evan Gershkovich Might Face Inside Russia’s Notorious Prisons
item.description: Evan Gershkovich, The Wall Street Journal reporter, was convicted on fabricated charges and is expected to serve time in one of the country’s infamous prisons.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, on Friday during the verdict announcement at the Sverdlovsk Regional Court in Yekaterinburg, Russia.

item.title: The White House Has a Plan to Slash Plastic Use in the U.S.
item.description: The government said it would phase out its purchases of single-use plastics, a significant step because it is the biggest buyer of consumer goods in the world.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.category: White House Council on Environmental Quality
item.media:description: The goal of the administration’s plan is to reduce demand for plastics and encourage a market for reusable or compostable alternatives.
